Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Evolution in the Eastern Mediterranean Campanulaceae - Integrating Information Management and Scientific Workflows in Daily Research and Teaching
Award.AbstractNarration:
CAREER: Evolution in the Eastern Mediterranean Campanulaceae - Integrating Information Management and Scientific Workflows in Daily Research and Teaching
This project will explore biological diversity and biogeography of Campanulaceae (bell flower family) in the Mediterranean Basin in order to understand plant population dynamics in continental islands that are under extraordinary pressure from humans and animals. The intricate geological history and the significant human pressure on the environment have dramatically shaped the biodiversity of this region. Many endemic species are confined to restricted localities, and are threatened and highly dependent on habitat conservation. Moreover, an ever-increasing need to extend phylogenetic analyses to additional markers and taxa underlines a grand challenge for informatics and computational sciences. Therefore, this research will integrate science and technology by developing a novel research environment where the data generated will be automatically processed into relevant analytical workflows. This approach to scientific analyses is more efficient, but hard to achieve without the technical skills and appropriate infrastructure.
The results of this research will have an impact on conservation planning by better informing researchers, educators, policy and decision makers about species dynamics in ecosystems like the Mediterranean (e.g., in California). A fundamental strength is the integration of science and technology research with training and curriculum development for K-12 and higher education. Outreach to the public will be through a museum exhibit developed at the Florida Museum of Natural History. This project will increase technology capacity and will serve not just as a test-bed but also importantly, as a foundational library that biological scientists, educators, and others can use.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study provides a broad, evolutionary perspective on Campanulaceae, a diverse clade of flowering plants, also known as bellflowers, encompassing more than 2300 species inhabiting myriad habitats from tropical rainforests to arctic tundra. The remarkable habitat diversity and cosmopolitan distribution of this group of organisms appear to be the result of a complex history of genome duplications and numerous, long-distance dispersal events.

During our studies, we focused specifically on Campanulaceae species in the Mediterranean Basin – a unique hotspot of biodiversity. While the western Mediterranean Basin has been relatively well studied, the eastern Basin remains poorly understood. With a high degree of endemism, when many species occur only on one island or one-to-a-few localities on the mainland, this region affords a unique opportunity to better understand the evolutionary processes affecting biodiversity in the Basin. The geologic and climatic history of the eastern Mediterranean Basin since the Miocene is a complex combination of tectonic events, sea level changes, volcanism, and a trend toward summer drought and increased seasonality. All of these events, in addition to human pressure, have had a profound effect on the flora and fauna of this area.  

We have shown that the evolutionary history and current distributional patterns of these plant species are the result of both long and short distance dispersal, in addition to islands isolation due to many sea level changes through the Miocene and onward. More specifically, our results indicate the break-up of an ancient Aegean landmass (today’s Aegean Archipelago) to be responsible for driving the evolution of these plants. Contrastingly, climatic shifts beginning approximately 8 million years ago, and eventually leading to the current Mediterranean climate, appear to be responsible for a decrease of the evolutionary rates in this group. Consequently, many species are now only found in restricted localities, increasing their risk of extinction. 

We also found that sometimes the entire genome content of these plants duplicates and leads to new biodiversity that is hard to observe because plants have the same morphological characteristics but different genomes. Species that exhibit this ability seem to have had an advantage in being able to spread widely across long distances and over a relatively short time, in contrast with closely related species that are only found in one-to-a-few localities.

By studying these plants in an evolutionary and geographic context, we highlighted the diversity and complexity of historical processes driving evolution in the Mediterranean Basin. This study will serve as a framework for future research not only on Campanulaceae species but also on other species living in similar habitats.
